review.title: FMAP: Distributed Cooperative Multi-Agent Planning
review.abstract: This paper proposes FMAP (Forward Multi-Agent Planning), a fully-distributed multi-agent planning method that integrates planning and coordination. Although FMAP is specifically aimed at solving problems that require cooperation among agents, the flexibility of the domain-independent planning model allows FMAP to tackle multi-agent planning tasks of any type. In FMAP, agents jointly explore the plan space by building up refinement plans through a complete and flexible forward-chaining partial-order planner. The search is guided by $h_{DTG}$, a novel heuristic function that is based on the concepts of Domain Transition Graph and frontier state and is optimized to evaluate plans in distributed environments. Agents in FMAP apply an advanced privacy model that allows them to adequately keep private information while communicating only the data of the refinement plans that is relevant to each of the participating agents. Experimental results show that FMAP is a general-purpose approach that efficiently solves tightly-coupled domains that have specialized agents and cooperative goals as well as loosely-coupled problems. Specifically, the empirical evaluation shows that FMAP outperforms current MAP systems at solving complex planning tasks that are adapted from the International Planning Competition benchmarks.

metadata.title: FMAP: Distributed Cooperative Multi-Agent Planning

sections.text: Although FMAP is specifically designed to address issues requiring collaboration between agents, the flexibility of the domain-independent planning model enables FMAP to perform planning tasks with multiple agents of each type. In FMAP, agents jointly explore the planning space by creating refinement plans through a complete and flexible, forward-looking sub-order planner. Search is led by hDTG, a novel heuristic function based on the concepts of the Domain Transition Graph and the Border State and optimized to evaluate plans in distributed environments. Agents in FMAP apply an advanced data protection model that allows them to adequately store private information while communicating only the data of the refinement plans relevant to each of the participating agents. Experimental results show that FMAP is an all-purpose approach that efficiently solves tightly coupled domains.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most of us will be able to play by the rules we have set ourselves.

sections.heading: 2 Related work
sections.text: In the literature, we then focus on two main approaches to solving MAP tasks as described in Example 1. Centralized MAP involves the use of a facilitator who has full knowledge of the task. Therefore, the distributed or decentralized approach spreads planning responsibility among the actors responsible for interacting with each other to coordinate their local solutions if necessary [28,18]. Adopting a centralized approach aims to improve planners "performance by exploiting the inherent structure of MAP tasks [22,8]. However, centralized approaches assume a single planning unit that has complete knowledge of the task, which is quite unrealistic if the parties involved in the task are unwilling to disclose their private information. In Example 1, the three actors involved in the task want to protect information relating to their internal processes and business strategies.

sections.heading: 3 MAP task formalization
sections.text: Agents in FMAP operate with limited knowledge of the planning task, assuming that information not represented in an agent model is unknown to the agent. < Assigning a value d to a variable v ² V generates a fluent. A positive fluent is a tuple < v >, indicating that the variable v takes the value d. A negative fluent is of the form < v, ¬ d >, indicating that v ² does not take the value d. A positive fluent is a set of positive and negative fluents.An action is a tuple.

sections.heading: 4 FMAP refinement planning procedure
sections.text: The FMAP is based on a cooperative refinement of the planning procedure in which the agents jointly explore a multi-agent, plan and space search tree. sections.heading: 5 Experimental results
sections.text: This year it is so far that it is only a matter of time before it will be so far, until it is so far.

sections.heading: 5.2.1 Loosely-coupled domains
sections.text: The five loosely coupled domains presented in Table 1 are: Blocksworld, Driverlog, Rover, Satellite and Zenotravel. The main feature of these domains is that agents have the same planning capabilities (operators) so that each task goal can be solved individually by a single agent. That is, tasks can be tackled without collaboration between agents. Next, we offer an insight into the characteristics of these domains and the MAP adjustments. Satellite [24]. This domain offers a simple multi-agent decomposition [25,37]. The MAP domain has one agent per satellite. The resulting MAP tasks are almost decoupled, as each satellite can achieve a subset of task goals (even all goals) without interacting with another agent. The number of agents in the tasks of this domain varies from 1 to 12. The location, orientation and instruments of a satellite are private to the agent.

sections.heading: 5.2.2 Tightly-coupled domains
sections.text: This year, it is as far as ever in the history of the city, where it is as far as never before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: FMAP is a universal MAP model that naturally supports distributed domains and defines an expanded concept of privacy. Agents in FMAP use an internal POP process to calculate all possible ways to refine a plan that guarantees the completeness of FMAP. Agents exchange plans and their evaluations using a communication mechanism managed by a coordinator-agent. FMAP uses the structure of distributed, state-independent domain transition graphs for heuristic evaluation of plans, thereby avoiding the need to recalculate estimates in each node of the POP search contract. Privacy is maintained throughout the search process.Agents communicate only the relevant information they share with the rest of the agents. This advanced concept of privacy is very useful for modeling real-world problems. Experiments show that dealing with privacy has a relatively low impact on the overall performance of FAP's 2013 MAPs. The MAPs in the MAPs indicate that other MAPs in the MAPs will have an impact on the overall performance.

The complexity of a MAP task is often described by means of its coupling level [4], which is measured as the number of interactions that arise among agents during the resolution of a MAP task.

Centralized approaches assume a single planning entity that has complete knowledge of the task, which is rather unrealistic if the parties involved in the task have sensitive private information that they are not willing to disclose [32].

The work in [7] introduces a distributed coordination framework based on partial-order planning that addresses the interactions that emerge between the agents’ local plans.
The proposal in [36] is based on the iterative revision of the agents’ local plans.
The approach in [39] uses multi-agent plan repair to solve inconsistencies among the agents’ local plans while maintaining privacy.
μ-SATPLAN [9] extends a satisfiability-based planner to coordinate the agents’ local plans by studying positive and negative interactions among them.

Plan-merging techniques are not very well suited for coping with tightly-coupled tasks as they may introduce exponentially many ordering constraints in problems that require great coordination effort [7].
For instance, Planning First [25] introduces a cooperative MAP approach for loosely-coupled tasks, in which specialized agents carry out planning individually through a state-based planner.
The resulting local plans are then coordinated by solving a distributed Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) [16].
This combination of CSP and planning to solve MAP tasks was originally introduced by the MASTRIPS framework [4].
One of the first approaches to domain-independent MAP is the Generalized Partial Global Planning (GPGP) framework [23].

Threats are addressed by introducing either an ordering constraint γ ≺ α (this is called demotion because the causal link is posted after the threatening action) or an ordering β ≺ γ (this is called promotion because the causal link is placed before the threatening action) [12].

Some MAP models consider that two parallel or non-sequential actions are mutually consistent if neither of them modifies the value of a state variable that the other relies on or affects [5].
We also consider that the preconditions of two mutually consistent actions have to be consistent [3].

Also, TFPOP [22] applies a centralized forward-chaining POP for multiple agents, keeping a sequential execution thread per agent.

Frontier states allow us to make use of state-based heuristics such as hFF , the relaxed planning graph (RPG) heuristic of FF [15].
Since none of the agents has knowledge that is complete enough to build an RPG by itself, using hFF to estimate the quality of a refinement plan involves agents building a distributed RPG [42].
Therefore, the predictable high computational cost of the application of hFF led us to discard this choice and opt for designing a heuristic that is based on Domain Transition Graphs (DTGs) [14].
A DTG is a directed graph that shows the ways in which a variable can change its value [14].

Additionally, POP is independent of the assumption that actions must be instantaneous or have the same duration and allows actions of arbitrary duration and different types of temporal constraints to be defined as long as the conditions under which actions interfere are well defined [34].

Most multi-agent applications nowadays make use of middleware multi-agent platforms that provide them with the communication services required by the agents [27].
The entire code of FMAP is implemented in Java and builds upon the Magentix2 platform [35].
Magentix2 agents communicate by means of the FIPA Agent Communication Language [26].

This subsection compares the experimental results of FMAP and MAPR [2].
MAPR is implemented in Lisp and uses LAMA [29] as the underlying planning system, without using a middleware platform for multi-agent systems.
Of the most recent MAP systems, MAPR is one that offers excellent performance in comparison to other state-of-the-art MAP approaches [2].
Each agent subtask is solved with the single-agent planner LAMA [29] such that the resulting subplans are progressively combined into a global solution.
That is, MAPR is built under the assumption that each goal must be addressed by at least one of the agents in isolation [2].

metadata.abstractText: This paper proposes FMAP (Forward MultiAgent Planning), a fully-distributed multi-agent planning method that integrates planning and coordination. Although FMAP is specifically aimed at solving problems that require cooperation among agents, the flexibility of the domain-independent planning model allows FMAP to tackle multi-agent planning tasks of any type. In FMAP, agents jointly explore the plan space by building up refinement plans through a complete and flexible forward-chaining partial-order planner. The search is guided by hDTG, a novel heuristic function that is based on the concepts of Domain Transition Graph and frontier state and is optimized to evaluate plans in distributed environments. Agents in FMAP apply an advanced privacy model that allows them to adequately keep private information while communicating only the data of the refinement plans that is relevant to each of the participating agents. Experimental results show that FMAP is a general-purpose approach that efficiently solves tightly-coupled domains that have specialized agents and cooperative goals as well as loosely-coupled problems. Specifically, the empirical evaluation shows that FMAP outperforms current MAP systems at solving complex planning tasks that are adapted from the International Planning Competition benchmarks.
